bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 20, 1951

div1.p: Hench informs Blossom of a celebration at the Bellevue Medical Center honoring her father. Blossom has compared Hench to her father, for which he is deeply honored.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 20, 1951
div1.opener:
September 20, 1951
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for sending me the most interesting program of the
celebration at your father's birthplace. I am delighted to have this
and am so glad that you were able to represent the family.

The Dean of the Bellevue Medical Center is a personal friend of mine and a
couple of weeks ago (rather tardily) I was notified about a celebration
to be held there on September 13. I think they were going to have a tea
and some sort of exhibit regarding your father's activities at Bellevue
years ago. Whether or not they had any speeches or formal program I do
not know. I sent them a long telegram to celebrate the occasion, a copy
of which I enclose.

During our correspondence, they first spoke of your father as a graduate
of Bellevue, 1897. This was obviously an error. Later they informed me
he was listed as a graduate of 1873, but thanks to your kindness I was
able to correct that and write them that I actually had the diploma and
that the date of his graduation was October 1, 1872. I have offered to
give to the Bellevue Hospital and New York Medical College a photograph
of his medical diploma. I am sure that you would not object and indeed
I think you would like to have me do this. I am certainly glad to do it.
More and more I am being called upon to give data regarding your father.
At the moment I have three requests for information, not to speak of the
voluminous correspondence which I recently had with Mrs. Standlee. I am
delighted of course to be of service and I think that it shows the
propriety of collecting together as much data as possible and having one
place where information will always be available.

Perhaps I was presumptuous in suggesting to the Dean of Bellevue that you
and your brother be invited to he ceremony. Obviously you had to be
elsewhere.

I must also thank you most sincerely for your gracious letter of September 3.
To have you compare me with your beloved father is of course about the greatest
compliment you could ever pay me. I do think that your father and mine were
much alike. They belonged to the old school of classical scholars to whom
right was right; they had no doubt about what was right or wrong; they be-
lieved in gentle but definite discipline and certainly Father kept my nose
to my books.

One point in your letter was particularly useful. You wrote “Father loved
Doctor Lazear and Doctor Carroll and they loved him.” I must always remember
that because certain of Doctor Carroll's actions after your father died,
some of his letters, remarks and so forth, one simply has to regard with
considerable charity and from time to time I feel a little stern toward
Carroll but, as you say, while your father was alive Carroll served him
faithfully and your father loved him. That is the important point which
I must remember and which gives me strength to maintain a charitable viewpoint
toward Carroll who, after all when he wrote some of the disturbing things,
must have been a rather sick man.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
